QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED FOR APPOINTMENT AND PROMOTION.

For Assistant Engineer.

12. The candidate must not be less than 18 nor more than 25 years of age, and he must produce certificates of service in a steam factory for at least four years. If not in possession of a certificate of competency as a 2nd-class or 1st-class Engineer, he will, if in India, be examined by the Inspector of Machinery of the dockyard and a Chief or other senior Engineer and such other person as the Director or Deputy Director of the Royal Indian Marine may think fit to select, as to his ability as a workman at the several trades a knowledge of which is requisite for the performance of his duties; he will also be examined in the practical use of the various instruments employed in the engine-room, and in the duties generally of a Marine Engineer; and no candidate will be entered unless the examining Officers certify that his skill as a
workman, his knowledge of machinery, and his good and steady conduct fully qualify him for the appointment.

13. On completion of the sea time required by the Board of Trade, Assistant Engineers of the Royal Indian Marine will obtain the permission of their commanding officers to present themselves for examination, and report the result thereof to them for the information of the Director of the Royal Indian Marine. Officers in command of the Royal Indian Marine vessels will see that the Assistant Engineers under their orders present themselves for examination for certificates of competency as 2nd and 1st class Engineers, as soon as they complete their sea time, and will submit to the Director of the Royal Indian Marine a report containing any explanation that may be necessary, of every instance in which an Assistant Engineer on board his vessel neglects to be examined in proper time. In the event of an Assistant Engineer failing to present himself for examination within twelve months after completing the necessary sea service, and being unable to furnish a satisfactory explanation, or in the event of his attaining the age of 27 years without obtaining a Board of Trade certificate of competency as a 1st class Engineer, a report on his case will be submitted to the Government of India, in order that it may be considered whether his further retention in the service is desirable. Failure on the second trial to obtain a certificate as 2nd or 1st class Engineer will involve a loss of three months' seniority; and should an Assistant Engineer fail a third time, his case will be submitted for the orders of the Government of India.

Engineer.

14. To qualify for appointment as an Engineer, an Officer must have served as an Assistant Engineer on Rs. 150 per mensem in an Indian Government vessel for three years, and be in possession of a certificate of competency as a 1st-class Engineer either from the Board of Trade, or from a Colony, or from one of the Local Government Boards in India.

15. The Government of India reserve the right which they have always exercised of admitting Officers from other services or departments to any class of the establishment or of making promotions on public grounds irrespective of seniority.

16. Promotions to the grade of Chief Engineer will be made wholly by selection, by the Government of India, on the recommendation of the Director of the Royal Indian Marine. Chief Engineers will be promoted to the Rs. 400 grade only after twenty years' service.

17. When certificated and uncertificated Engineers are serving on board the same vessel, the certificated Engineers will take precedence above the uncertificated Engineers.

18. A ship's Engineer transferred to a dockyard appointment will be seconded, and a promotion made in his place. If brought back again on the establishment, he will be borne as supernumerary till absorbed. Officers temporarily transferred will not be seconded; but acting promotions will be made in such cases, and in the room of Officers absent on furlough or leave.

Note.—In paragraphs 7, 8, 9, and 14, the certificates of competency referred to as being obtained from one of the Local Government Boards in India are those equivalent to the Board of Trade or Colonial Certificates, and do not include those known as "First-class Local Indian Home Trade Certificates."

FURLOUGH AND LEAVE RULES OF THE ROYAL INDIAN MARINE.

1884 Rules.

Furlough.

I.—Officers after five years' service in India or under the Government of India, exclusive of all periods of absence on furlough, may receive one year's furlough, and an additional year for each subsequent five years' service. Furlough not taken at the time it becomes due is not lost, and can, subject to these Regulations, be taken later.

II.—An officer may not be absent from duty on any grounds for more than three years consecutively, nor on return from furlough may he receive, except under Rule VII., any further furlough until after an interval of three years.

III.—Furlough may be spent anywhere, and when it has been earned by length of service, counts as service for pension. Furlough taken before it is earned by length of service reckons against service for pension till paid off.

IV.—An officer on furlough in receipt of the rate of pay in force before 1st April, 1886, receives half the pay of his rank, or if holding a shore appointment, half the pay of his appointment, excluding command, charge, acting, personal, or house allowance, computed according to a rate of exchange to be fixed in each year by the Secretary of State. An officer on the new rates of pay will draw, when on furlough, half the pay of his grade plus half the staff allowance of his appointment. An officer promoted while on furlough will be entitled to a moiety of the increased pay due to that promotion.

V.—An officer proceeding on or returning from furlough may be granted an advance of three months' furlough pay; and he may further* be granted the advance in aid of passage money specified in clause IX. if he does not obtain passage by troopship. Advances made in England will be recovered in India by monthly instalments of one-fourth of the pay drawn by the officers, which will include all permanent or temporary allowances drawn by them. This recovery will be made at the official rate of exchange fixed for the year in which the advance is made. Advances made in India will be noted on the last pay certificates of officers, and no

* Unless holding shore appointments of Rs. 1,000 per mensem. Such officers are ineligible for passage by troopship (cl. ix.) and are also ineligible for any advance exceeding three months' Furlough pay. Marine Circular, No. 1 of 1888.
issue of furlough pay will be made till after the sum advanced has accrued as furlough pay.

VI.—Furlough pay may not be drawn for more than two years consecutively.

VII.—Upon certificate of a Medical Board, an officer not entitled to furlough, who has served not less than one year in India, may be granted furlough. Such furlough will not count of service for pension until it has been paid off by subsequent service under the terms of Rule I. Furlough cannot be anticipated beyond two years in the aggregate, nor for a second term, unless that previously anticipated has been subsequently paid off under the terms of Rule I.

VIII.—An officer who has exhausted the furlough obtainable under these Rules, and who may be certified by a Medical Board to be still unfit for duty, will be retired on the pension or gratuity to which he may be entitled; if not entitled to either pension or gratuity, his case will be specially considered (but see under heading "Temporary Retirement," on p. 292).

IX.—Marine officers not holding shore appointments of Rs. 1,000 per mensem will be eligible for the grant of non-regulation passages in troopships when such passages are available. Officers who do not obtain passages in troopships will be allowed advances* in aid of passage money, in addition to the advances admissible under Clause V., provided that no officer shall in any case draw advances exceeding three months' pay in all.

X.—Furlough, whether on private affairs or on medical certificate, is restricted to a maximum period of one year in the first instance, and to subsequent extensions not exceeding six months at a time.

General Leave.

XI.—General leave may be granted for any period not exceeding six months at a time, but cannot be renewed, except for very urgent reasons, till after two years have elapsed from its expiration. It may be spent anywhere, does not involve forfeiture of appointment, and counts as service for pension. It will be granted or refused entirely at the discretion of the Director of the Indian Marine. It may be granted up to a maximum limit of 30 days as subsidiary to furlough, whether on proceeding on furlough or on return from furlough. Leave granted as subsidiary to furlough can only be spent in India. The grant of furlough out of India carries with it the grant of the subsidiary leave admissible under this clause.

XII.—During general leave an officer will be restricted to the pay of his grade,† and will forfeit all allowances, which will be paid to his locum tenens. If an officer exceeds the six months' leave admissible at one time under this Rule, the entire period will be converted into furlough, and his allowances adjusted accordingly. The advances of pay sanctioned under Rule V. are not admissible to officers proceeding on or returning from general leave.

Privilege Leave.

XIII.—Subject to the exigencies of the service, Marine officers may be allowed 60 days' privilege leave during each year, and each leave may be taken in instalments.

XIV.—An officer who has privilege leave to his credit when proceeding on leave or furlough does not forfeit it, but privilege leave cannot be taken in continuation of furlough, nor can furlough be obtained in continuation of privilege leave. Privilege leave may, however, be converted into general leave with the sanction of the Director of the Indian Marine, or into furlough with the sanction of the Government of India.

XV.—Privilege leave will be granted by the Director of the Indian Marine, but it will be granted only on the understanding that no additional expense is thereby caused to the State, either directly or indirectly, that the applicant's services can be spared, and that satisfactory arrangements for the performance of his duties during his absence can be made.

XVI.—Officers are at liberty to proceed wherever they may desire when on privilege leave, provided they can ensure their return before the expiration of the leave. If an officer exceeds his privilege leave, the whole period of his absence will be converted into general leave or furlough, and his allowances and statement of service for furlough adjusted accordingly.

Temporary Leave.

XVII.—Temporary leave not exceeding 10 days, and not in anticipation or extension of any kind of leave or furlough, may be granted by the Director and Deputy Director of the Indian Marine.

XVIII.—Temporary leave not exceeding 72 hours may be granted by commanders of vessels and heads of departments to officers under their command.

General Regulations.

XIX.—It must be distinctly understood that furlough or leave cannot be claimed as a right. Both are subject to the exigencies of the public service, and will be granted only when an officer's services can be spared. Commanders of vessels and heads of departments will not forward an application for furlough or leave unless they are able to satisfy the Director of the Indian Marine that the officer's services can be spared without any inconvenience to the public service. An officer who has not completed his term of probation for the Marine Service, cannot be granted leave with retention of his probationary appointment in excess of three months.

XX.—No grant of leave given under the conditions of these Rules will count against an officer's service for pension, and leave may be spent anywhere, i.e., within possible limits of return before it expires.

XXI.—Leave is reckoned from the day on which an officer avails himself of it, and it expires on the day he rejoins.

Furlough reckons from date of leaving India, or from date of leaving his ship if at an out-station, unless specially stated by authority to commence on an earlier date, and ceases on the day of return to India.

The day of return from leave is a day of duty, also that of return from furlough, where duty commences at port of disembarkation.

XXII.—Officers on furlough in Europe will draw their pay from the India Office, but officers

* See footnote preceding page.
† This Rule will also hold good in the case of an officer holding a shore appointment, in which case the balance will be considered a staff allowance payable to the locum tenens provided the latter does not thereby draw more than the pay of the appointment.
on general or privilege leave must arrange to draw their pay in India.

XXIII.—As a rule leave will be granted only during the period of the south-west monsoon.

XXIV.—Officers proceeding on furlough will report their departure personally at the office of the Director or Deputy Director of the Indian Marine, except when they avail themselves of it at an out-station. An officer returning from furlough or leave will rejoin the ship to which he belongs; but if this is impracticable, and he has not received instructions (which he should apply for beforehand), he will rejoin at Bombay or Calcutta, reporting himself in person to the Director or Deputy Director. On the departure of an officer on furlough or leave, or on the return of an officer therefrom, the commander of the vessel will cause an entry to be made of the date in the ship's log-book, and will forward an extract thereof by the next post to the Director. Except when orders are sent to the contrary, all officers returning from furlough will report themselves to the Director of the Royal Indian Marine at Bombay.

XXV.—Officers arriving in Europe on furlough or on general leave must report their arrival in writing to the Military Secretary at the India Office, and state their address; and for extension of furlough or for permission to return to duty, they must also apply to the Military Secretary. Before applying for extension of furlough on private affairs they must obtain permission to do so from the Government of India, through the Director of Marine. The permission thus obtained must be attached to the application for extension, and submitted to the Military Secretary at the India Office.

Officers proceeding to the colonies on furlough should apply to India for extension of furlough and for permission to return to duty.

XXVI.—During the absence of an officer on leave or furlough, he must keep the Director of the Royal Indian Marine acquainted with his actual address, and be prepared to return immediately to India, should his services be required. When on leave, such recall order will be issued by the Director; when on furlough in Europe, by the Secretary of State. Officers spending their furlough in Europe must keep the Secretary of State informed of their address.

XXVII.—Proceedings of Medical Boards on officers of the R.I.M. invalided to Europe should state—

I.—Whether the illness is the result of climate, and caused in and by the service.

II.—Whether change of climate in or out of India is necessary.

III.—The period of absence recommended in or out of India.

XXVIII.—No officer on leave or furlough may take service under any other employer in India without special sanction.

NOTE.—The above rules are applicable to—

I.—Officers on the Graded and Supernumerary List of Executive Officers.

II.—Officers on the Graded List of Engineers.

III.—Gazetted clerks,

IV.—Warrant officers who may be specially admitted to the rules.

1892 RULES.

1. These rules shall apply to—

(a) All officers appointed to the Indian Marine after 26 April, 1892.

(b) Officers who elected them within one year of the date of their publication.

Note.—The term "officers" includes the Graded and Supernumerary List of Executive Officers and the Graded List of Engineers.

2. Those who apply for leave of any kind within one year of the date of publication of these rules must make their election when submitting their applications for leave; all others, whether on duty or on furlough or leave on 26 April, 1892, may elect at convenience within the specified time.

3. All officers who elect these rules will come under their provisions from the date of the receipt of their applications by the Government of India if they are in India, or at the India Office if they are at home; and they will be entitled to count all past furlough and leave as service for pension under Rule V.

4. Those who elect these rules while on furlough or general leave under the previous regulations will be allowed the option of continuing to draw any furlough or leave allowances they may be in receipt of under those regulations, if more advantageous, until the expiry of such furlough or general leave or any extension thereof which would have been admissible under the previous regulations, subject to the limit of two years' absence from duty.

5. It must be clearly understood that officers who do not elect these rules within the period stated will be held to have declined them, and will be allowed no further opportunity of electing them.

6. "General leave" and "subsidiary leave" will not be granted to officers under these rules.

Rules.

I.—An officer subject to these rules may be granted—

(a) Privilege leave and temporary leave under such regulations as may from time to time be in force.

(b) Leave in or out of India for one year, capable of extension to two years' absence from duty under conditions stated below.

Leave in or out of India other than privilege or temporary leave.

An officer promoted while on leave will be entitled to the higher rate of leave pay from date of promotion.

III.—Leave may be granted at any time at the discretion of the Government of India, on the recommendation of the Director of the Royal Indian Marine. Leave in or out of India not exceeding six months may be granted by the Director of the Royal Indian Marine without previous reference to the Government of India, a report of such leave being made for notification in Government General Orders.

IV.—Extensions of leave in or out of India in excess of one year, but not exceeding two years' absence from duty in all, may be granted on medical certificate or on special or urgent grounds, at the discretion of the sanctioning authority. The previous assent of the Government of India will be required for extensions, except on medical certificate, and must be obtained by the applicant through the Director of the Royal Indian Marine. Extensions beyond two years' absence from duty will only be admissible in very special cases, and without any pay whatever.

V.—Leave in or out of India will reckon as service for pension.

VI.—Leave will commence on the date of being struck off duty, except that in the case of an officer having to appear before a Medical Board the date of being struck off duty will mean the date on which he quits the station where he is examined and invalided. In cases of leave out of India on medical certificate the period of leave recommended by a Medical Board as necessary will be held to commence on the date of quitting India. In all cases, however, an officer will be due to rejoin his ship or appointment at the expiry of the period granted to him, the day on which he rejoins it being reckoned as a day of duty.

VII.—An officer unable on account of ill health to return to his duty within the maximum period of two years' absence will, unless specially granted leave without pay, be placed on temporary or permanent retirement, according to the circumstances of his case. An undue amount of leave on account of ill health will likewise render an officer liable to be transferred to temporary or permanent retirement.

VIII.—An officer on leave in or out of India will be required to rejoin his appointment at once on being recalled to duty on account of the exigencies of the service, unless pronounced by a Medical Board to be unfit to do so.

IX.—An officer proceeding on leave will report his departure personally at the office of the Director or Deputy Director of the Royal Indian Marine, except when he avails himself of it at an out-station. Except when ordered to the contrary, all officers returning from leave will report themselves to the Director of the Royal Indian Marine at Bombay.

An officer arriving in Europe on leave must report his arrival in writing to the Military Secretary at the India Office, and state his address; and for extension of leave or for permission to return to duty, he must also apply to the Military Secretary. An officer applying for extension of leave on private affairs must, except in very special or urgent circumstances, attach an intimation of the assent of the Government of India.

An officer proceeding to the Colonies on leave should apply to India for extensions of leave and for permission to return to duty.

X.—Leave pay under these rules, when issued out of India, will be converted into sterling at the official rate of exchange in force for the period when the pay becomes due, as fixed annually for the adjustment of financial transactions between the India and Imperial Governments.

XI.—Advances not exceeding three months' full pay of grade, subject to a limit of 100l. to Commanders, and 65l. to officers of junior rank, will be allowed on proceeding on or returning from leave, and on returning from temporary retirement. Advances made in England will be recovered in India by monthly instalments of one-fourth of the pay drawn by the officers, which will include all permanent or temporary allowances drawn by them. This recovery will be made at the official rate of exchange fixed for the year in which the advance is made. Advances made in India will be noted on the last pay certificates of officers, and no issue of leave pay will be made till after the sum advanced has accrued as such. In case of death no recovery of advances made under this rule is to be effected from the estate of the deceased officer.

XII.—Marine officers not holding shore appointments of 1,000 rupees per mensem will be eligible for the grant of non-regulation passages in troopships when such passages are available.

Privileges and Temporary Leave under these Rules.

XIII.—Subject to the exigencies of the service, Marine officers may be allowed 60 days' privilege leave during each year, and such leave may be taken in instalments.

XIV.—Accumulated privilege leave for 90 days may be granted to an officer who has no privilege leave during the preceding 33 months, but no "leave in or out of India," if exceeding six months, can be counted as part of the fixed 33 months.

XV.—An officer who has privilege leave (ordinary or accumulated) at his credit, when proceeding on "leave in or out of India," does not forfeit it, but privilege leave cannot be taken in continuation of "leave in or out of India," nor can "leave in or out of India" be taken in continuation of privilege leave.

Privilege leave may, however, be converted into "leave in or out of India" with the sanction of the Government of India.

XVI.—An officer returning from accumulated privilege leave granted in one year and extending into the next is eligible for ordinary privilege leave during the period when such leave is avail-
able in the year in which he returns, provided he rejoins before proceeding on ordinary privilege leave.

XVII.—Privilege leave will be granted by the Director of the Royal Indian Marine, but only on the understanding that no additional expense is thereby caused to the State either directly or indirectly, that the applicant's services can be spared, and that satisfactory arrangements for the performance of his duties during his absence can be made.

XVIII.—Privilege leave (ordinary or accumulated) reckons as service for pension.

XIX.—As a rule privilege leave will only be granted during the period of the south-west monsoon.

XX.—Officers are at liberty to proceed wherever they may desire when on privilege leave, provided they can ensure their return before the expiration of the leave. If an officer exceeds his privilege leave the whole period of his absence will be converted into "leave in or out of India," and his allowances and statement of service for "leave in or out of India" adjusted accordingly.

XXI.—Privilege leave is reckoned from the day on which an officer avails himself of it, and it expires on the day he rejoins, the day of return being reckoned as a day of duty.

XXII.—An officer of the floating establishment returning from privilege leave will, if possible, rejoin the ship to which he belongs, but if this is impracticable, and he has not received instructions (which he should apply for beforehand), he will rejoin at Bombay or Calcutta, reporting himself in person to the Director or Deputy Director. On the departure of an officer on privilege leave or on the return of an officer therefrom, the Commander of the vessel will cause an entry to be made of the date in the ship's log, and will forward an extract thereof by the next post to the Director.

XXIII.—Temporary leave not exceeding 10 days' and not in anticipation or in extension of any other kind of leave, may be granted by the Director and Deputy Director of the Royal Indian Marine.

XXIV.—Temporary leave not exceeding 72 hours may be granted by Commanders of vessels and heads of departments to officers under their command.

General Regulations.

XXV.—It must be distinctly understood that leave in or out of India, or privilege leave, cannot be claimed as a right. Both are subject to the exigencies of the public service, and will be granted only when an officer's services can be spared. Commanders of vessels and heads of departments will not forward an application for privilege or other leave unless they are able to satisfy the Director of the Royal Indian Marine that the officer's services can be spared without any inconvenience to the public service.

XXVI.—An officer who has not completed his term of probation for the Marine service cannot be granted leave with retention of his probationary appointment in excess of three months.

XXVII.—The proceedings of Medical Boards on officers of the Royal Indian Marine should state:

1. Whether the illness is the result of climate, and caused in and by the service.
2. Whether change of climate in or out of India is necessary.
3. The period of absence recommended in or out of India.

XXVIII.—The name of an officer granted leave out of India (other than privilege leave), will be removed from the ship on which borne, and he will draw his pay during such leave—

(a) if proceeded to Europe, through the India Office.
(b) if proceeded to any colony named in the list in Appendix No. 17 of the Civil Service Regulations, in such colony.

He can, however, draw his leave pay in India if he prefers it.

XXIX.—The name of an officer, granted leave in India (other than privilege leave), will be removed from the ship on which borne, and he will draw his pay during such time from any treasury in India in communication with the Examiner of Marine Accounts.

XXX.—The name of an officer, granted privilege leave (ordinary or accumulated), will continue on the books of his ship, and he will draw his pay either from the ship or from any treasury in India or through a bank or agent, as may be arranged through the Examiner of Marine Accounts.

XXXI.—During the absence of an officer on leave (privilege or otherwise), he must keep the Director of the Royal Indian Marine acquainted with his actual address and be prepared to return immediately to India, should his services be required. When on privilege leave, such recall order will be issued by the Director; when on leave in Europe (other than privilege), by the Secretary of State. Officers spending their leave (other than privilege) in Europe must keep the Secretary of State informed of their address.

XXXII.—The Secretary of State in Council reserves to himself the right of making any change in the foregoing rules which circumstances may require.

MARINE CIRCULAR No. 13, DATED 6TH OCTOBER, 1891

(As revised by Marine Circular No. 3, dated 1st August, 1893).

Rules for the Instruction in England of Officers of the Royal Indian Marine in Gunnery and the use of Torpedoes, and in other scientific branches of their profession.

In supersession of Marine Circular No. 7, of the 27th April, 1891, the Governor-General in Council is pleased, with the approval of the Secretary of State for India, to notify the following rules for the instruction in England of officers of the Royal Indian Marine in gunnery and the use of torpedoes, and in other scientific branches of their profession.
2. All officers and engineers of the Royal Indian Marine, whether in India or on leave or furlough in England, are at liberty to apply for permission to attend all courses and classes open to officers or engineers of the Royal Navy on full pay, including the courses at the Royal Naval College, Greenwich.

3. There will in future be no restriction on the number of officers or engineers undergoing instruction at the same time.

4. The courses are:

For Officers—
(I.) Short course for Lieutenants, consisting of eight weeks' each of gunnery and torpedo.
(II.) The session of the Royal Naval College, Greenwich, for Captains, Commanders, Lieutenants, and Navigating Officers, which commences on the 1st October in each year, and lasts till the 30th June following.

For Engineers—
(I.) Course on board the "Vernon" and "Excellent;" the former beginning in January, March, and April, and lasting for 45 days each; the latter commencing in February, April, and June, and lasting for 25 days each.
(II.) A course at the Royal Naval College, Greenwich, which usually begins in October of each year.

5. Every officer or engineer permitted to attend a course will be on duty for the period he may be under instruction, and if on leave or furlough, except leave on medical certificate, such period will be reckoned as in addition to his leave or furlough.

6. Officers and engineers attending courses will be entitled to full grade pay, together with subsistence and travelling allowances for that period.

7. Officers and engineers failing to qualify, except on account of sickness, will, if on leave or furlough, lose all the advantages of being on duty during the period of instruction; that is to say, they will be restricted to their grade or furlough pay, as the case may be.

8. It is therefore to be understood that officers and engineers while under instruction will be granted their full pay, subject to adjustment under paragraph 7, but the subsistence allowance will be withheld until the termination of the course, as it will only be admissible to officers who pass.

9. Should the Government of India select an officer or engineer to undergo instruction at home, either on board the training ships or at the Royal Naval College, Greenwich, or elsewhere, or to go through a combined course at more than one centre of instruction, he will be given a free passage to England and back, and will be considered on duty while under instruction, and will also receive full pay and subsistence and travelling allowances, subject to the operation of Rule 8.

10. If an officer so selected and sent to England at the public expense fails to obtain a certificate at the termination of the course, he will be placed on furlough pay for the period of his absence from India.

11. The cases of all officers prevented by sickness from completing a course of instruction will be considered as they arise.

12. In forwarding applications from officers on leave or furlough for permission to undergo instruction, the Director of the Royal Indian Marine should be careful to see that no infringement of the furlough regulations is likely to take place from the application being granted. No officer will be selected who has not sufficient leave unexpired at the commencement of the course to enable him to return to duty on its termination, or who cannot be granted an extension of leave under existing furlough rules.

13. The Director of the Royal Indian Marine should also satisfy himself that applicants are likely to qualify in the subject in which they desire to receive instruction. In the case of Engineer officers desirous of being admitted to study at the Royal Naval College, Greenwich, the Director will, before forwarding their applications, cause them to pass an examination based on that which has to be undergone by Engineer students of the Royal Navy.

14. Officers in future, when applying for permission to attend courses of instruction, should specify the particular course or courses which they desire to enter. Their applications should be forwarded to the Government of India in time to allow of the Secretary of State's sanction being obtained before the commencement of the course; and recommendations for permission to allow officers to undergo instruction should be made by the Director of the Royal Indian Marine as soon after their departure from India as possible, especially in the case of officers on general leave.

15. The subjects of examination at the Royal Naval College, Greenwich, will be—

I.—Mathematics;
II.—Navigation, theoretical and practical;
III.—Compass adjustment;
IV.—Steam;
V.—Physics, only magnetism (but with electricity for those passing to the "Vernon" for torpedo course);
VI.—Surveying;

and 40 per cent. of marks upon these subjects on the papers set to the senior officers will entitle officers to a qualifying certificate. If, further, an officer should obtain the honorary certificate, he will have the letter "G" placed against his name in the list of officers of the Royal Indian Marine.

16. Officers will be at liberty to take up meteorology, practical astronomy, or any other subject of the senior officer's course as optional subjects.

CONDITIONS OF TEMPORARY RETIREMENT OF OFFICERS OF THE ROYAL INDIAN MARINE.

(Sanctioned by Despatch to Government of India, No. 369, dated 16th December, 1886.)

Officers of the Royal Indian Marine, who, after exhausting the furlough admissible to them are unfit for service, but not irremediably broken in health, may be temporarily transferred to the retired list. Temporary retirement is subject to the condition that the disease which necessitates it must have been contracted in and by the service.

An officer granted temporary retirement may be permitted to remain in that position till his total continuous absence from duty, on furlough and temporary retirement together, amounts to four years. If then still unfit to return to duty, he must be placed on the permanent retired list, receiving the pension (if any) or gratuity for which he had qualified at the time of being granted temporary retirement.

No period spent on temporary retirement will count as service for pension, nor will an officer be eligible for promotion while he is in that position. An officer replaced on the effective list, on becoming fit to return to duty, will be restored to the grade from which he retired, and his name will be placed in the same numerical position in that grade which it occupied at the time of temporary retirement.

Officers will be required to appear before a Medical Board at the expiration of one year on temporary retirement, and again, if retained in that position, before the end of the second year; and those who, in view to being restored to the effective list, may wish to appear before the Board at other times than those specified, may be permitted to do so. Officers ordered periodically to appear before the Board will be allowed, in the United Kingdom, their bona fide travelling expenses, and lodging allowance at the rates stated below, but those appearing at other times, and at their own wish, must do so at their own expense.

**Rates of Lodging Allowances.**

| Lieutenant | 4 0 |
| Sub-Lieutenant | 3 0 |
| Chief Engineer | 5 0 |
| Engineer | 4 0 |
| Assistant Engineer | 3 0 |
PENSION REGULATIONS OF THE ROYAL INDIAN MARINE.

1885 RULES.

1. The following is the scale of pensions and compassionate allowances admissible to officers and engineers of Her Majesty's Indian Marine to their families.

2. The service for pension of an officer of the Marine reckons from date of joining his ship or appointment if he is 19 years of age or over; otherwise from date of attaining that age.

3. An officer admitted to the Service after 30 years of age will be subject to reduction of pension by one-fortieth for every year or part of a year by which his age at the commencement of his qualifying service exceeded 30 years.

4. Retirement at the age of 55 years will be compulsory, and all officers and engineers of that age now in the Service, as well as those who may attain that age within one year, will be required to retire at the expiration of one year from the date of this order. The amount of superannuation pension is that which would be admissible as an invalid pension. (Marine Circular No. 8 of 1888.) Should an officer holding the appointment of Director or Deputy Director of the Indian Marine attain that age during his incumbency, he may, with the approval of the Government of India, complete five years in the appointment.

**INDIAN NURSING SERVICE.**

**CONDITIONS OF APPOINTMENT, &c.**

1. The Nursing Establishment consists of two grades, viz.:

   (1.) Lady Superintendents.
   (2.) Nursing Sisters.

   Note.—The term "lady nurse" as used in the following paragraphs includes both the above grades.

2. Nursing Sisters must be, at the time of appointment, over 25 and under 35 years of age, and before admission to the service they must be examined by the President of the Medical Board at the India Office as to their fitness for service in India. They must have had at least three years' preliminary training and service combined in a hospital in which adult male patients receive medical and surgical treatment, and in which a staff of Nursing Sisters is maintained.

3. The duration of a term of service, for all grades of lady nurses, is five years, capable of renewal for a further five years at the option of the Government, with the consent of the lady nurse.

A lady nurse pronounced by a Medical Board to be physically fit for further service in India, and who may be specially recommended by the Commander-in-Chief India for an extension of service, will be permitted to serve for a third term, and, in very exceptional cases, for a fourth term of five years.

4. The engagement may, however, be terminated at any time on six months' notice being given, either on the part of the Government or of the lady nurse (but see para. 12).

**Rates of Pay.**

(In addition to free quarters, fuel, light, and punkah-pullers.)

5. For a Lady Superintendent ... Rs. 300 per mensem.
   For a Nursing Sister ... 175
Indian Nursing Service—continued.

commencing from the date of embarkation for India.

A Senior Nursing Sister acting as Superintendent at a station where no lady superintendent is located, receives an additional allowance of Rs. 25 per mensem.

Leave in India.

6. Leave on medical certificate, up to a maximum of six months during the whole of the five years' term of service, may be granted to a lady nurse by the Principal Medical Officer of Her Majesty's Forces; during such leave, which will reckon as service, she will receive two-thirds of the salary of her grade. Short leave and privilege leave may be granted at the discretion of the local authorities and as circumstances may admit.

Leave out of India.

7. After engagement for a second, third, or fourth term of service, a lady nurse may be granted one year's leave from duty, on two-thirds pay, with free passage by sea and rail from and to her station. This leave may be extended, on medical certificate, on two-thirds pay up to two years' absence from duty: provided that in the opinion of the India Office Medical Board there is a reasonable prospect of fitness to return to duty within that period. Such period will not reckon as service in any way.

Gratuities.

8. The following rates of gratuities are payable to lady nurses on completion of their total Indian service:

|----------------------------------------|---------------------|

|                                        | As a nursing sister, with Rs. 140 additional for each complete year's service as lady superintendent. |

|                                        | Rs. 240             |

9. No gratuity is given for service terminated by any other cause than sickness or the completion of the terms of 5 and 10 years' service.

Pensions.

10. Lady nurses retiring after completion of 15 or 20 years' total service will be entitled to pension at the following rates:

| Nursing Sister, per annum. | Lady Superintendent |
|----------------------------|---------------------|
| After 15 years' service    | £50                 |
| " 20 "                     | As Nursing Sister, with £2 additional for each completed year's service in the grade of Lady Superintendent. |

11. A lady nurse compelled by ill-health to retire after 15 but under 20 years' total service will receive a pension of £50 a year, with an increment of £2 for each completed year over 15 years' service, and an additional £2 a year, in the case of a Lady Superintendent, for the total number of years served in that grade.

12. A lady nurse compelled by ill-health to retire after 10, but under 15 years' service will be granted such rate of pension, below that fixed for 15 years' service, as may be determined by the Secretary of State for India in Council on the recommendation of the Government of India.

13. If paid in India, these pensions will be payable in Indian currency at the rate of exchange annually fixed for the adjustment of transactions between the Imperial and Indian Governments.
Passage, &c.

14. Passage at the public expense, subject to a deduction of 2s. a day for messing while on board ship, is granted to lady nurses when proceeding to India on appointment, when returning home on leave (under paragraph 7) on completion of a term of service, or if invalided home before the completion of a term. They are entitled to take 6 cwt. of baggage. Lady nurses are also entitled to travelling expenses on the above occasions from their places of residence in England to port of embarkation, and from port of disembarkation in India to destination in that country, and vice versa.

Claims for conveyance of baggage must be supported by vouchers. Agency and dock charges are inadmissible.

15. An outfit allowance on appointment is made at the rate of £25 for each Lady Superintendent, and £15 for each Nursing Sister.

16. A lady nurse who resigns (except on account of ill-health), with less than five years' Indian service, will forthwith refund the sum of £20 in respect of her passage out (or £30 if she have failed to give the notice required by Rule 4), and will not be entitled to a passage home.

17. A lady nurse who has re-engaged for a second term of service in India will be subject to the same penalties if she resigns (except on account of ill-health) without giving six months' notice, but not otherwise.

18. Lady nurses must be prepared to embark, if necessary, not later than 30 days from date of appointment.

The following article is compiled principally from Sir William Hunter's 'Imperial Gazetteer'. A few corrections have been made from the same author's 'Indian Empire' (3rd ed., 1893) and from other sources; and the statistics have been brought up to date as far as possible.

The term Rx. used in these pages means tens of rupees.

India forms a great irregular triangle, stretching southwards from mid-Asia into the ocean. Its northern base rests upon the Himalayan ranges; the chief part of its western side is washed by the Arabian Sea, and the chief part of its eastern side by the Bay of Bengal. It extends from the eighth degree to the thirty-fifth degree of north latitude; that is to say, from the hottest regions of the equator to far within the temperate zone. The capital, Calcutta, lies in 88° E. long.; so that when the sun sets at six o'clock there, it is just past mid-day in England. The length of India from north to south, and its greatest breadth from east to west, are both about 1,900 miles; but the triangle tapers with a pear-shaped curve to a point at Cape Comorin, its southern extremity. To this compact dominion, the English have added, under the name of Burma, the strip of country lying between India proper on the west, and Chinese and Siamese territory on the north and east, and extending southwards along the eastern shore of the Bay of Bengal. The whole territory thus described contains 1,560,160 square miles, and 287 millions of inhabitants. India, therefore, has an area and a population about equal to the area and population of the whole of Europe, less Russia. Its people more than double Gibbon's estimate of 120 millions for all the races and nations which obeyed Imperial Rome.

India is shut off from the rest of Asia on the north by a vast mountainous region, known in the aggregate as the Himalayas. Among their southern ranges lie the independent states of Bhutan and Nepal; the great table-land of Tibet stretches behind. The subordinate native principality of Kashmir, with its dependencies of Hunza, Nagar, Chitral, &c., occupies their north-western Indian angle. At this north-western angle an allied mountain system branches southwards, and separates India from Afghanistan. India is bounded along the west and south-west by the Arabian Sea and Indian Ocean. Turning northwards from its southern extremity at Cape Comorin the Bay of Bengal forms the main part of its eastern boundary. But in the north-east, as in the north-west, India has again a land frontier. The Himalayan ranges at the north-eastern angle of India throw off long spurs and chains to the southward. These spurs separate Assam and Burma from the outlying and semi-independent states and provinces of the Chinese Empire. Proceeding south-eastwards, after touching for a short distance territory under French influence in the basin of the Mekong, the boundary marches with Siam southwards to Point Victoria at the extremity of Tenasserim.

These are the territorial limits of what is generally understood by the term India; but the political control exercised by the Indian government extends over a considerably larger area. Baluchistan, of which a part, designated British Baluchistan, is a Chief Commissionership under direct British administration, is wholly subject to its political control. Afghanistan, Nepal, and Bhutan are allied states within the sphere of British influence. In addition, the Indian Empire includes the island groups of the Andamans, Nicobars, and Laccadives; the settlement of Aden, with Perim, the Somali coast protectorate on the neighbouring African mainland, and protectorates over the island of Sokotra, along the southern coast of Arabia, and in the Persian Gulf.

Physical Aspect.—The empire included within these boundaries is rich in varieties of scenery and climate, from the highest mountains in the world to vast river deltas raised only a few inches above the level of the sea, and consists of three separate and well-defined tracts.

The first of the three regions is the Himalaya Mountains and their offshoots to the southward. The Himalayas consist of a system of stupendous ranges, the loftiest in the world. They are the Emodus or Imaus of the Greek geographers, and extend in the shape of a scimitar, with its edge facing southwards, for a distance of 1,500 miles along the northern frontier of India. At the north-eastern angle of that frontier, the Dihang river, the connecting link between the Tsan-pu (Sangpu) of Tibet and the Brahmaputra of Assam, bursts through the main axis of the Himalayas. At the opposite, or north-western angle, the Indus in like manner pierces the range, and turns southwards on its course through the Punjab. The Himalayas, like the Kuen-luen chains, the Tien-shan, and the Hindu Kush, converge towards the Pamir tableland—that central knot whence all the great mountain systems of central Asia radiate. The Himalayas have been divided into three principal chains; but regarded merely as a natural frontier separating India from the Tibetan plateau, they may be described as forming a double mountain wall running nearly east and west, with a trough or series of deep valleys beyond. The southernmost of the two walls rises steeply from the plains of India to 20,000 feet, or nearly four miles, in height. It culminates near its centre in
Kanchanjanga, 28,176 feet, and Mount Everest, 29,002 feet, the latter being the loftiest measured peak in the world. This outer or southern wall of the Himalayas subsides on the northward into a series of dips or uplands, 13,000 feet above the level of the sea, beyond which rises the second or inner range of Himalayan peaks. The double Himalayan wall thus formed then descends into a great trough or line of valleys, in which the Sutlej, the Indus, and the mighty Tsan-pu (Sangpu) gather their waters. The Sutlej and the Indus flow westwards, and pierce by separate passes through the western Himalayas into the Punjab. The Tsan-pu (or Sangpu), after a long unexplored course eastwards along the valley of the same name in Tibet, finds its way through the Dihang gorge of the Eastern Himalayas into Assam, where it takes its final name of the Brahmaputra. On the north of the river trough, beyond the double Himalayan wall, rise the Karakoram and Gangri mountains, which form the immediate escarpment of the Tibetan tableland. Behind the Gangris, on the north, the lake-studded plateau of Tibet spreads itself out at a height averaging 15,000 feet. Broadly speaking, the double Himalayan wall rests upon the low-lying plains of India, and descends into a river trough beyond which rises the Tibetan plateau. The higher ranges between Tibet and India are crowned with eternal snow, while vast glaciers, one of which is known to be 60 miles in length, slowly move their masses of ice downwards to the valleys.

This wild region is in many parts impenetrable to man, and nowhere yields a passage for a modern army. Ancient and well-known trade routes exist, by means of which merchandise from the Punjab finds its way over heights of 18,000 feet into Eastern Turkistan and Tibet. The Mustagh (Snowy Mount), the Karakoram (Black Mount), and the Chang-chenmo are the most famous of these passes.

The Himalayas, at both their eastern and western extremities, send out ranges to the southwards, which protect the north-eastern and north-western frontiers. On the north-east, those offshoots, under the name of the Naga and Patkoi Mountains, &c., form a barrier between the civilised districts of Assam and the wild tribes of Upper Burma. The southern continuations of these ranges, known as the Yomas, are crossed by passes, the most historic of which, the Aeng or An, rises to 4,668 feet, with gradients of 472 feet to the mile.

On the opposite or north-western frontier of India, the mountainous offshoots run down the entire length of the British boundaries from the Himalayas to the sea. As they proceed southwards, their best marked ranges are in turn known as the Safed Koh, the Sulaiman, and the Hala Mountains. These massive barriers have peaks of considerable height, culminating in the Takht-i-Sulaiman, or Throne of Solomon, 11,317 feet above the level of the sea. But the mountain wall is pierced at the corner where it strikes southwards from the Himalayas by an opening through which the Indus river flows into India. An adjacent opening, the Khaibar Pass (rising to 3,400 feet), with the Kuram Pass to the south of it, the Gwalari Pass near De'a Ismail Khan, the Tal Pass debouching near Dera Ghazi Khan, and the famous Bolan Pass (5,800 feet at top), still farther south, furnish the gateways between India and Afghanistan. The Hala, Brahui, and Pab Mountains form the southern hilly offshoots between India and Baluchistan, and have a much less elevation.

The Himalayas, while thus standing as a rampart around the northern frontier of India, collect and store up water for the tropical plains below. Throughout the summer, vast quantities of water are evaporated from the Indian Ocean. This moisture is borne northward by the monsoon or regular wind, which sets in from the south in the month of June. The monsoon carries the masses of cloud northward across India, and thus forms the 'rainy season,' on which agriculture so critically depends. But large quantities of the moisture do not fall as rain in passing over the hot plains. This vast residue is eventually dashed against the Himalayas. Their lofty double walls stop its farther progress northwards; and it either descends in rain on their outer slopes, or is frozen into snow in its attempt to cross their inner heights. Very little gets beyond them; so that while their southern spurs receive the largest measured rainfall in the world, and pour it down to the Indian rivers, the great plateau of Tibet on the north of the double wall gets scarcely any rainfall.

This heavy rainfall of the Himalayas renders the southern slopes of that range very fertile, wherever there is any depth of tilth. But, on the other hand, the torrents scour away the surface soil, and leave most of the mountain-sides bleak and bare. The upper ranges lie under eternal snow; the intermediate heights form arid grey masses; but on the gentler slopes, plateaux, and valleys, forests spring up, or give place to a rich though simple cultivation. The temperature falls about 34° F. for each thousand feet of elevation; and the vegetation of the Himalayas is divided into three well-marked zones, the tropical, the temperate, and the arctic, as the traveller ascends from the Indian plains. A damp belt of lowland, the tarai, stretches along their foot and is covered with dense, fever-breeding jungle, habitable only by rude tribes and wild beasts.

The wide plains watered by the Himalayan rivers form the second of the three regions above referred to. They extend from the Bay of Bengal on the east, to the Afghan frontier and the Arabian Sea on the west, and contain the richest and most densely-crowded provinces of the Empire. One set of invaders after another have, from pre-historic times, entered by the passes on the north-eastern and north-western frontiers. They followed the courses of the rivers, and pushed the earlier comers southwards before them towards the sea. About 165,000,000 of people now live on and around these river plains in the provinces known as the Lieutenant-Governorship of Bengal, Assam, the North-Western Provinces, Oudh, the Punjab, Sind, Rajputana and other native states.

The vast level tract which thus covers Northern India is watered by three distinct river-systems. One of these river-systems takes its rise in the hollow trough beyond the Himalayas, and issues through their western ranges as the Sutlej and Indus. The second also takes its rise beyond the double wall of the Himalayas, not very far from the sources of the Indus and the Sutlej. It turns, however, almost due east instead of west, enters India at the eastern extremity of the Himalayas and becomes
the Brahmaputra of Assam and Eastern Bengal. The third river-system receives the drainage of the southern Himalayan slope, and unites into the mighty stream of the Ganges, which flows south-eastwards into the Bay of Bengal.

The third division of India comprises the three-sided tableland which covers the southern half, or more strictly peninsular, portion of India. This tract, known in ancient times as the Deccan, literally the South, comprises the Central Provinces, Berar, Madras, Bombay, Mysore, with the native territories of the Nizam, Sindha, Holkar, and other feudatory states. The Deccan, in its local acceptation, is restricted to the high tract between the Narbada and the Kistna rivers; but it is popularly understood to include the whole country south of the Vindhyas as far as Cape Comorin. It slopes up from the southern edge of the Gangetic plains. Three ranges of hills support its northern, its eastern, and its western sides, the two latter meeting at a sharp angle near Cape Comorin.

The northern side rests on confused ranges, running with a general direction of east to west, and known in the aggregate as the Vindhya mountains. The Vindhyas, however, are made up of several distinct hill systems. Two sacred peaks stand as outposts in the extreme east and west, with a succession of ranges stretching 800 miles between. At the western extremity, Mount Abu, famous for its exquisite Jain temples, rises, as a solitary outlier of the Aravalli Hills, 5,650 feet above the Rajputana plains, like an island out of the sea. On the extreme east, Mount Parasnath—like Mount Abu on the extreme west, sacred to Jain rites—rises to 4,400 feet above the level of the Gangetic plain.

The various ranges of the Vindhyas, from 1,500 to over 4,000 feet high, form, as it were, the northern wall and buttresses which support the central tableland. Now pierced by road and railway, they stood in former times as a barrier of mountain and jungle between Northern and Southern India, and formed one of the main difficulties in welding the whole into an empire. They consist of vast masses of forests, ridges, and peaks, broken by cultivated valleys, and broad high-lying plains.

The other two sides of the elevated southern triangle are known as the Eastern and Western Ghats. These chains start southwards from the eastern and western extremities of the Vindhyas, and run along the eastern and western coasts of India. The Eastern Ghats stretch in fragmentary spurs and ranges down the Madras Presidency, receding inland and leaving broad, level tracts between their base and the coast. The Western Ghats form the great sea-wall of the Bombay Presidency, with only a narrow strip between them and the shore. The Eastern Ghats have an average elevation of 1,500 feet. The Western Ghats ascend more abruptly from the sea to an average height of about 3,000 feet, with peaks up to 4,700, along the Bombay coast; rising to 7,000 and even 8,760 feet in the upheaved angle where they unite with the Eastern Ghats, towards their southern extremity.

The inner triangular plateau thus enclosed lies from 1,000 to 3,000 feet above the level of the sea. But it is dotted with peaks and seamed with ranges exceeding 4,000 feet in height. Its best known hills are the Nilgiris (Blue Mountains), with the summer capital of Madras, Ootacamund, 7,000 feet above the sea. Their highest point is Dodabetta peak, 8,760 feet, at the upheaved southern angle.

On the eastern side of India, the Ghats form a series of spurs and buttresses for the elevated inner plateau, rather than a continuous mountain wall. They are traversed by a number of broad and easy passages from the Madras coast. Through these openings, the rainfall of the southern half of the inner plateau reaches the sea. The drainage from the northern or Vindhyan edge of the three-sided tableland falls into the Ganges. The Narbada and Tapti carry the rainfall of the southern slopes of the Vindhyas and of the Satpura Hills, by two almost parallel lines, into the Gulf of Cambay. But from Surat, in lat. 21° 28', to Cape Comorin, in lat. 8° 4', no great river succeeds in piercing the Western Ghats, or in reaching the Bombay coast from the interior tableland. The Western Ghats form, in fact, a lofty unbroken barrier between the waters of the central plateau and the Indian Ocean. The drainage has, therefore, to make its way across India to the eastwards, now twisting sharply round projecting ranges, then tumbling down ravines, or rushing along valleys, until the rain which the Bombay sea-breeze has dropped upon the Western Ghats finally falls into the Bay of Bengal. In this way, the three great rivers of the Madras Presidency, viz., the Godavari, the Kistna, and the Kaveri, rise in the mountains overhanging the Bombay coast, and traverse the whole breadth of the central tableland before they reach the sea on the eastern shores of India.

It is on the three-sided tableland, and among the hilly spurs which project from it, that the mineral wealth of India lies hid. Coal-mining now forms a great industry on the north-eastern side of the tableland, in Bengal; and also in the Central Provinces. Beds of iron-ore and limestone have been worked in several places. Many districts are rich in building stone, marbles, and the easily worked laterite. Copper and other metals exist in small quantities. The diamonds of Golconda were long famous. Gold dust has from very ancient times been washed out of the river-beds; and quartz-crushing for gold is being attempted on scientific principles in Madras and Mysore.

To this vast empire, the English have added Burma, an account of which will be given further on.

Population.—The population of India, including Burma, but omitting French and Portuguese possessions and the frontier states of Baluchistan, Nepal, and Bhutan, amounted in 1891 to 277,223,431, or, as already mentioned, more than double the number which Gibbon estimated for the Roman empire in the height of its power. Over one-third of the country still remains under the government of hereditary native chiefs, whose subjects make up 66,000,000 (exactly, 66,050,479) or something over one-fifth of the whole Indian people. The British territories, therefore, comprise only two-thirds of the area of India, and about four-fifths of its inhabitants.

The native princes generally govern their states with the help, and under the advice, of a political officer appointed by the British Government and residing at their courts. Some of them administer the internal affairs of their States with almost complete independence; others require more assistance, or a stricter control. These feudatory rulers possess revenues and
armies of their own, and the more important exercise the power of life and death over their subjects; but the authority of each is limited by treaties or engagements, or recognised practice by which their 'subordinate dependence' on the British government is determined. That government, as suzerain in India, does not allow its feudatories to make war upon each other, or to form alliances with foreign states. It interferes when any chief misgoverns his people; rebukes, and, if needful, removes the oppressor; protects the weak; and firmly imposes peace upon all.

The British possessions are distributed into twelve governments, each with a separate head; but the whole is under the orders of the supreme government of India, consisting of the governor-general in council. The governor-general, who also bears the title of viceroy, holds his court and government at Calcutta in the cold weather, and during summer at Simla, 7,000 feet up the Himalaya mountains. The viceroy of India, and the governors of Madras and Bombay, are usually British statesmen appointed in England by the Queen. The heads of the other provinces are selected for their merit from the Anglo-indian services, and are nominated by the viceroy, subject, in the case of the lieutenant-governors, to the approval of the Secretary of State.

Statistics relating to the population of India, including the Native States, are given at page 338.

British India supports a population more than twice as dense as that of the native states. If we exclude the outlying and lately-acquired provinces of Burma and Assam, the proportion is nearly threefold, or 279 persons to the square mile. How thick this population is, may be realised from the fact that France had, in 1891, only 186 people to the square mile; while even in crowded England, wherever the density approaches 200 to the square mile, it ceases to be a rural population, and has to live, to a greater or less extent, by manufactures, mining, or city industries. Throughout large areas of Bengal, two persons have to live on the proceeds of each cultivated acre, or 1,230 persons to each cultivated square mile. The Famine Commissioners reported in 1880, that over six millions of the peasant holdings of Bengal, or two-thirds of the whole, averaged from two to three acres a-piece. Allowing only four persons to the holding, for men, women, and children, this represents a population of twenty-four millions struggling to live off fifteen million acres, or a little over half an acre a-piece.

Unlike England, India has few large towns, and no great manufacturing centres. Thus, in England and Wales, 53 per cent., or over one-half of the population in 1891, lived in towns with upwards of 20,000 inhabitants; while in British India only 4.84 per cent., or not one-twentieth of the people, live in such towns. India, therefore, is almost entirely a rural country, and many of the so-called towns are mere groups of villages, in the midst of which the cattle are driven a-field, and ploughing and reaping go on. Calcutta itself has grown out of a cluster of hamlets on the banks of the Hugli; and the term 'municipality,' which in Europe is only applied to towns, often means in India a 'rural union,' or collection of homesteads for the purposes of local government.

We see, therefore, in India, a dense population of husbandmen. Wherever their numbers exceed one to the acre, or 640 to the square mile, excepting in suburban districts or in irrigated tracts, the struggle for existence becomes hard. In such districts, a good harvest yields just sufficient food for the people, and thousands of lives depend each autumn on a few inches more or less of rainfall. The Government may, by great efforts, feed the starving in time of actual famine; but it cannot stop the yearly work of disease and death among a steadily underfed people.

In some parts of India, therefore, there are more husbandmen than the land can feed; in other parts, however, vast tracts of fertile soil still await the cultivator. In England, the people would move freely from the over-populated districts to the thinly-inhabited ones; but in India the peasant clings to his hereditary homestead long after his family has outgrown his fields. If the Indian races will only learn to migrate to tracts where spare land still abounds, they will do more than the utmost efforts of Government can accomplish to prevent famines.

The facts disclosed by the census in 1881 and 1891 prove, indeed, that the Indian peasant has lost something of his old immobility. The general tendency of the population in Bengal is south and east to the newly-formed delta, and north-east to the thinly-peopled valleys or Assam. In 1891, it was ascertained that out of a specified population of 287,000,000, nearly 10,910,000, or about 4 per cent., were living in provinces in which they had not been born. But the clinging of the people to their old villages, in spite of hardship and famine, still forms a most difficult problem in India.
